This is a settlement event card found in the Kingdom Death: Monster Core Game.

Card Text.
A low rumbling fills the settlement. Small cracks in the earth widen into fissures that belch up hot, foul-smelling vapor.

Lingering Effects.
The cracks prevent all Home endeavors.
The vapor imprives breathing! +1 to the result of Nightmare Training endeavors.

Vapor Visions - spend 3 organs, roll 1d10.
 Requires Shrine

Vapor Scar - spend 3 resources, roll 1d10.
 Requires Scarification

Notes.
The Vapor Visions section of this card states that players require the "Hunt Shrine" innovation. This is an incorrect reference to the Shrine innovation.

is a settlement event card found in the Kingdom Death: Monster Core Game.
Card Text.
A cloaked woman enters the settlement. All that can be seen
beneath her hood is the sparkle of perfect teeth. She offers to
improve the survivors if they are brave enough.

Lingering Effects.

Mend Bones.
Cost: 3 x bone or 1 x skull:
The woman fixes your broken mouth. Heal the shattered jaw severe injury.

Monster Tooth Dentures*.
Cost: 4 x bone or 1 x large flat tooth:
The woman upgrades your mouth. Gain +1 permanent strength once per lifetime.

Metal Jaw*.
Cost: 4 x bone or 1 x large flat tooth:
Gain the following ability. Metal Maw: Your Fist & Tooth attacks gain Sharp.
----

Before gaining the benefits of Monster Tooth Dentures or Metal Jaw, roll 1d10 to see if the surgery was a success.

is a settlement event card found in the Gambler's Chest Expansion.
Card Text.
1. The survivors wander, drawn by a comfortable rumbling sound. They find the serene comfort in a towering sphere of snoring bodies held aloft by a massive robed figure. Within its long robes, survivors rest peacefully. On a deep, instinctual level, they know this area is safe, and make their home.

Roll 1d10 to determine your starting population.

2. The First Crimson Day will not be used again this campaign. Remove it from your settlement event deck.

See Also.
First Day

is a settlement event card found in the Kingdom Death: Monster Core Game.
Card Text.
The First Day settlement event will help set up your settlement. It is the first event of any new campaign.

1. The survivors wander, drawn to a blooming light in the distance. They find the serene comfort of a towering pile of lanterns and a small collection of scared people. On a deep, instinctual level, they know this area is safe, and they make it their home. 

Roll 1d10 to determine your starting population and record the result on the back of the settlement record sheet. Choose and record genders for the unnamed survivors. You may name an unnamed survivor and create their survivor record sheet at any time during the settlement phase.

2. Return to the settlement section of the First Story and proceed to Returning Survivors.

The First Day settlement event card will not be used again during this campaign. Do not include it in your settlement event deck.

Notes.
Though it describes the Lantern Hoard found in a People of the Lantern campaign, this event is also used for People of the Sun and People of the Stars campaigns with no such location.

The survivor with the lowest hunt XP (choose in case of a tie) is convinced a powerful presence is nearby. Roll 1d10.

is a settlement event card found in the Kingdom Death: Monster Core Game.
Card Text.
Nominate the group's favorite survivor to play the Hunter. Nominate your least favorite survivor to play the Monster. Pick 1 monster from the settlement's list of defeated monsters.

Lamplighter is a scout settlement event card with the exclude symbol, introduced in the Gambler's Chest Expansion. It may be added to the settlement event deck during Lost to the Darkness.

Lamplighter.
A monster reaches the settlement. It blinks for the first time in years, breaking bacteria-rich deposits within its cavernous irises and causing a bioluminescent reaction. Its haloed gaze shines upon the settlement, frying its lanterns. The survivors' worst fears are realized. They panic, vomiting as they spread themselves flat on the ground.

Does the settlement have a Lantern Halberd or a Guidepost?.

is a settlement event card found in the White Speaker Sword Hunter white box expansion.

Card Text.
Do not add this event to the settlement event deck until instructed.

An imposing woman strides into the settlement, her back bristling with scabbards. She recites a story. Hearing her tale, the gathered survivor's arms droop limp at their sides, unable to weild a weapon or offer comfort. If the settlement has the Excalibur rare gear, the woman dispassionately slays its last wielder and sheathes it on her back. Archive it.

She demands the settlement presents its blades. Clumsily, the saggy-armed survivors drag them forth. Examing each blade, she samples a spot with her tongue. Nominate each sword, Twilight Sword, katana, and scimitar in the settlement. Roll 1d10 for each nominated weapon, one at a time.

After resolving, remove this from the settlement event deck.

Notes.
The intro text for this event erroneously says "the gathered survivors arms...", where the word "survivors" should be possessive.

is a settlement event card found in the Kingdom Death: Monster Core Game.
Card Text.
If you are the only player, a survivor dreams about a giant man that controls their lives from the darkness above. All departing survivors gain +3 insanity.

Otherwise...

The group must select a player to be the storyteller and a survivor to be the dreamer. The dreamer has a weird dream and the storyteller must tell the rest of the group all about it. The remaining players will vote to determine if the dream was well told and then consult the crowd reaction below.

Well Told - A truly amazing tale! The settlement is inspired and gains +1d5 Endeavors.

Poorly Told - The settlement boos and heckles the dreamer. Add the Nickname settlement event to the timeline next year and nominate the dreamer for it. Nominate 3 other survivors. Having a great laugh, they gain survival up to the current survival limit if they depart this year. The storyteller may not play as one of these survivors for the next hunt and showdown.

The selected player rolls 1d10 on each of the following tables to determine what the survivor's weird dream was about. The player should try their best to weave a compelling story to share with the other players and the settlement.
